stem: Dr. {{surname}}, you are called to the ward where a patient with a recent tracheostomy is in respiratory distress. The nursing staff tell you the tracheostomy tube appears displaced. How would you manage this situation?

prompts.text: Talk me through your immediate actions at the bedside.
expectedKeyFacts: Apply high-flow oxygen to face AND stoma simultaneously
Assess patency: look, listen, feel at mouth and stoma

prompts.text: The inner tube is clear but you still cannot ventilate through the tracheostomy. What now?
expectedKeyFacts: Pass suction catheter through tracheostomy — if it passes, tube is patent and in trachea
If catheter does not pass — tube is displaced or blocked
Cover the stoma and attempt oral bag-mask ventilation

prompts.text: You have removed the tracheostomy tube and are ventilating orally. The surgeon asks you to re-insert the tube. What are your concerns?
expectedKeyFacts: Fresh tracheostomy (<7 days) — tract not mature, do NOT blindly re-insert
Maintain oral intubation as the safe airway
If reinsertion needed, use fibreoptic guidance or surgical reinsertion
For mature tracheostomy (>7 days), reinsertion through established tract is safer

prompts.text: Why might you choose to intubate orally rather than attempt front-of-neck re-access in this scenario?
expectedKeyFacts: Oral intubation is a familiar, reliable technique
Fresh stoma is oedematous, bleeding risk
Buys time for senior surgical involvement
Risk-benefit: known technique vs uncertain anatomy

rescuePrompt: Perhaps you could talk me through the NTSP emergency tracheostomy algorithm — what are the key steps?
keyFacts: Call for help early — anaesthetic emergency
Apply oxygen to face AND stoma
Use suction catheter to assess patency
Use capnography to confirm ventilation route
If fresh tracheostomy (<7 days) — do NOT blindly re-insert
Cover stoma and ventilate from above if needed
Escalate to surgical team for definitive management

scoringGuidance.pass_plus: Systematic NTSP algorithm approach, clear on fresh vs mature tracheostomy distinction, appropriate escalation, articulates risk of false passage, considers fibreoptic guidance
scoringGuidance.pass: Covers ABC approach, removes inner cannula, attempts suction catheter, aware of reinsertion risks in fresh tracheostomy, mentions oral intubation as fallback
scoringGuidance.borderline: Some structure but gaps — may not distinguish fresh from mature tracheostomy, or misses suction catheter step, vague on when to remove tube entirely
scoringGuidance.fail: No structured approach, attempts blind reinsertion of fresh tracheostomy, does not apply oxygen to both face and stoma, unaware of NTSP algorithm
